PUOMC 389609 Discharge Summary Unsigned 214-61-48 ADMISSION DATE : 07/30/98 Subarachnoid hemorrhage . ASSOCIATED DIAGNOSIS : Ventriculostomy placement on 7/15/98 . HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS : Per his wife , he was otherwise without any symptoms . He was loaded with Dilantin , placed on Decadron and transferred to the Ph University Of Medical Center . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY : Remarkable for cerebrovascular accident in 1994 . His vital signs were remarkable for a blood pressure of 195/100 . His mental status exam showed him to be very sleepy and he moved to sternal rub and loud voice . He was oriented to his name , Ph University Of Medical Center and 1997 and was able to follow simple commands . His motor exam showed a slight right drift and he was not cooperative with cerebellar testing . His physical examination also showed pupils at 3-2 mm. bilaterally and he blinked to threat . His INR was 3.8 on admission . He had significant hydrocephalus with a small intraventricular hemorrhage . Mr. A was admitted to the Neurosurgery Service with a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage and hydrocephalus . He had a cerebral angiogram performed on July 15th which was unrevealing . He had a ventriculostomy placed by the Neurosurgery Service on July 15th . Neurologically , his lesions were inoperable , but he received treatment with Dilantin and the ventriculostomy tube to control his intracranial pressure . Infectious Disease issues included serial fevers of unknown source . Gastrointestinally , he was unable to tolerate tube feeds and was started on total parenteral nutrition . Mr. A 's neurologic condition was stable at the baseline exam as described above . This meeting took place on July 30th from 10:00 AM until approximately noon . The family decided at this time that they wished to withdraw care from Mr. A . Shortly thereafter , his arterial line was removed . Following this , at approximately 2:05 PM , his endotracheal tube was removed . Mr. A immediately became bradycardic and desaturated . At 2:10 PM on July 30th , he expired . Mr. A , was immediately notified . SAY REKE , M.D. DICTATING FOR : TELSHEY K. VITAL , M.D. TR : TD : cc :
165342718 181252 Unsigned Discharge Date : 12/07/1993 The patient is a 40 year old woman with end stage renal disease , on hemodialysis since 12/91 . He has been having difficult access problems and now has a left upper arm PTFE . Iron , Nephro-Caps , calcium carbonate and Valium . She was taken to the Operating Room on 11/30/93 where Dr. Tiveloydherdes performed a cadaveric renal allograft to the left iliac fossa which she tolerated well . Postoperative course was unremarkable . She was started on her immunosuppressive agents as per protocol . Her creatinine fell to the normal range early . She was gradually advanced to a regular diet . Her prednisone was tapered to a stable dose . IA A , M.D. AX37 Attending : Batch : 6066 Index No. VQCUHL4S7Y D : 12/07/93 12/08/93
PUOMC 5838116 768876 Signed Report Status : URKE , AMA L UNIT NUMBER : 12/09/2002 DISCHARGE DATE : OPERATIONS / PROCEDURES : HISTORY : Biopsy confirmed foci of astrocytoma . She was treated with XRT and PCV chemotherapy . She did well until recently when she developed difficulty with reading comprehension , word-finding , reversing words and letters . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY : Surgical history is as above . MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION : 4. Multivitamins . ALLERGIES : Cranial nerves intact . Tandem gait is unsteady . Heel-to-shin unsteady ; finger-to-nose was intact . Strength was 5/5 . HOSPITAL COURSE : Postoperatively , she had a right hemianopsia and an expressive aphasia . She was , otherwise , neurologically intact . She had a moderate expressive aphasia which was slightly worse than preoperatively . Postoperatively , she was watched in the ICU and transferred to the floor on postoperative day one . She worked with physical therapy and occupational therapy . Neuro-oncology was consulted . She will follow up with Dr. Kohmedlfreiermbeem in the brain tumor clinic . Postoperative MRI showed no evidence of residual . She was instructed to keep her incision dry until the sutures were out . She will call Dr. Celkkaysqian 's office for a follow-up appointment . A AH nurse will also visit her at home as well as home PT . WERN NEIGHELKS , M.D. DICTATING FOR : Electronically Signed LUPEVICKETTE L LIST , M.D. _____________________________ LUPEVICKETTE L LIST , M.D. TR : TD : 12/12/2002 8:42 A 794008 cc :
867290496 50889296 765801 Discharge Summary Unsigned Admission Date : 04/02/1991 Discharge Date : 04/09/1991 EPIGLOTTITIS . She was seen by her local internist after having several days of blood-tinged sputum which she was coughing up and some mild throat discomfort . She did not complain of significant pain and was able to tolerate p.o.s. She denied any respiratory distress although her family thought she may have had some labored breathing at one point . She was seen by her local physician who was concerned that she may have a malignancy secondary to the history of hemoptysis and throat discomfort . Examination by the local otolaryngologist appareantly revealed significant swelling in the epiglottic area although we had no true record of what was seen . Apparently the findings were significant enough to cause this otolaryngologist to recommend that the family bring the patient emergently to Ez Ephtro Health Center where she be admitted for steroids and antibiotics and apparently the question of a tracheostomy was raised . She was sitting straight upright although was not having any respiratory distress . She did report a lot of salive in the back of her throat . She was febrile to 101.7 . ENT consult was obtained . A lateral neck film revealed significant swelling of the epiglottis . Negative . None . ALLERGIES : None . FAMILY HISTORY : Negative . Alcohol none . The patient was sitting upright and was not drooling and was able to swallow her secretions although she did have a very wet voice which got progressively more hoarse during the examination . Neck : Otherwise normal and the trachea was midline . Hypopharyngeal examiantion revealed a severely edematous , yellowish-white epiglottis with significantly edematous base of tongue which had marked watery edema . The left pyriform was obliterated by edema . No masses . Back : LABORATORY EXAMINATION : Revealed a WBC count of 11.6 , H and H of 10.7 and 31.7 , platelet count of 268 , differential 94 polys , 0 bands , 5 lymphs , one mono . As noted above , lateral neck film revealed marked edema of the epiglottis . The chest x-ray showed signficant kiphosis with several areas of increased interstitial markings but otherwise negative . HOSPITAL COURSE : The patient was felt to have epiglottitis , possibly secondary to a malignancy , especially in her age group . She was started on IV Ceftriaxone two grams and was given humidification . She was taken to the Operating Room at approximately 2:00 a.m. which was approximately one hour after being evaluated by ENT and was intubated awake over a fiberoptic bronchoscope through the left nares with nasal anesthetic only with a #6 endotracheal tube . Her initial hospital course while intubated was significant for an episode of atrial fibrillation which she went into in the Operating Room . At the end of the case she had had a central line placed also for frequent blood draws at the request of the SICU house office . She had no trouble with blood pressure with this atrial fibrillation with rates going up to 150 . She was given a dose of Digoxin but broke spontaneously approximately two minutes after the Digoxin was given . EKG and enzymes were obtained and showed the first degree AV block that she had had on her preoperative EKG but no other findings at all . She went into an SVT the afternoon after intubation and a decision was made to Digitalize her , keeping her level between approximately .6 and 1 . Otherwise her examination was normal with good visualization of the larynx and significant decrease in size of the epiglottis . Once the steroids were stopped , the insulin was able to be stopped . After extubation she was watched in the ICU for 24 hours and she did well except for some episodes of confusion happening the night of extubation and also the next morning . O2 saturations looked good . Her white counts came down . Blood cultures which had been drawn at the time of intubation were negative . Her mental status began to clear under the family 's request . On 4/9/91 she was sent home on a week of Augmentin and will followup in the ENT Clinic . Our plan will be to establish whether or not she truly had an epiglottic lesion . Discharge medications are Augmentin 500 mg t.i.d. X 7 days . DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS : RG556/4903 EENTO WORKS , M.D. NL6 04/10/91 U5989C79 T : 04/10/91
